Background.text: The Futuna island group was discovered by the Dutch in 1616 and Wallis by the British in 1767, but it was the French who declared a protectorate over the islands in 1842. In 1959, the inhabitants of the islands voted to become a French overseas territory.

Location.text: Oceania, islands in the South Pacific Ocean, about two-thirds of the way from Hawaii to New Zealand

Area.note: includes Ile Uvea (Wallis Island), Ile Futuna (Futuna Island), Ile Alofi, and 20 islets

Geography.note: includes Ile Uvea (Wallis Island), Ile Futuna (Futuna Island), Ile Alofi, and 20 islets

Area - comparative.text: 1.5 times the size of Washington, DC

Climate.text: tropical; hot, rainy season (November to April); cool, dry season (May to October); rains 2,500-3,000 mm per year (80% humidity); average temperature 26.6 degrees C

Environment - current issues.text: deforestation (only small portions of the original forests remain) largely as a result of the continued use of wood as the main fuel source; as a consequence of cutting down the forests, the mountainous terrain of Futuna is particularly prone to erosion; there are no permanent settlements on Alofi because of the lack of natural fresh water resources

Geography - note.text: both island groups have fringing reefs

Net migration rate.note: there has been steady emigration from Wallis and Futuna to New Caledonia (2010 est.)

People.note: there has been steady emigration from Wallis and Futuna to New Caledonia (2010 est.)

noun.text: Wallisian(s), Futunan(s), or Wallis and Futuna Islanders

adjective.text: Wallisian, Futunan, or Wallis and Futuna Islander

Languages.text: Wallisian 58.9% (indigenous Polynesian language), Futunian 30.1%, French (official) 10.8%, other 0.2% (2003 census)

definition.text: age 15 and over can read and write

conventional long form.text: Territory of the Wallis and Futuna Islands

local long form.text: Territoire des Iles Wallis et Futuna

time difference.text: UTC+12 (17 hours ahead of Washington, DC during Standard Time)

Administrative divisions.text: none (overseas territory of France); there are no first-order administrative divisions as defined by the US Government, but there are three kingdoms at the second order named Alo, Sigave, Wallis

Legal system.text: the laws of France where applicable apply

chief of state.text: President Nicolas SARKOZY (since 16 May 2007); represented by High Administrator Michel JEANJEAN (since 10 June 2010)

head of government.text: President of the Territorial Assembly Victor BRIAL (since 11 December 2007)

cabinet.text: Council of the Territory consists of 3 kings and 3 members appointed by the high administrator on the advice of the Territorial Assembly

Executive branch.note: there are 3 traditional kings with limited powers

elections.text: French president elected by popular vote for a five-year term; high administrator appointed by the French president on the advice of the French Ministry of the Interior; the presidents of the Territorial Government and the Territorial Assembly elected by the members of the assembly

Government.note: as a territory of France, "La Marseillaise" is official (see France)

Legislative branch.text: unicameral Territorial Assembly or Assemblee Territoriale (20 seats; members elected by popular vote to serve five-year terms)

elections.text: last held on 1 April 2007 (next to be held in April 2012)

election results.text: percent of vote by party - NA; seats by party - UMP 13, other 7

Legislative branch.note: Wallis and Futuna elects one senator to the French Senate and one deputy to the French National Assembly; French Senate - elections last held on 21 September 2008 (next to be held by September 2014); results - percent of vote by party - NA; seats - UMP 1; French National Assembly - elections last held on 17 June 2007 (next to be held by 2012); results - percent of vote by party - NA; seats - PS 1

Judicial branch.text: justice generally administered under French law by the high administrator, but the three traditional kings administer customary law and there is a magistrate in Mata-Utu; a court of appeal is located in Noumea, New Caledonia

Political parties and leaders.text: Lua Kae Tahi (Giscardians); Mouvement des Radicaux de Gauche or MRG; Rally for the Republic or RPR (UMP); Socialist Party or PS; Taumu'a Lelei; Union Populaire Locale or UPL; Union Pour la Democratie Francaise or UDF

Flag description.text: unofficial, local flag has a red field with four white isosceles triangles in the middle, representing the three native kings of the islands and the French administrator; the apexes of the triangles are oriented inward and at right angles to each other; the flag of France, outlined in white on two sides, is in the upper hoist quadrant
Flag description.note: as a territory of France, "La Marseillaise" is official (see France)

Economy - overview.text: The economy is limited to traditional subsistence agriculture, with about 80% of labor force earnings from agriculture (coconuts and vegetables), livestock (mostly pigs), and fishing. About 4% of the population is employed in government. Revenues come from French Government subsidies, licensing of fishing rights to Japan and South Korea, import taxes, and remittances from expatriate workers in New Caledonia.

Agriculture - products.text: coconuts, breadfruit, yams, taro, bananas; pigs, goats; fish

Exchange rates.text: Comptoirs Francais du Pacifique francs (XPF) per US dollar - 87.59 (2007), 94.97 (2006), 95.89 (2005), 96.04 (2004), 105.66 (2003)

Broadcast media.text: the publicly-owned French Overseas Network (RFO), which broadcasts to France's overseas departments and territories, is carried on the RFO Wallis and Fortuna television and radio stations (2008)

Military - note.text: defense is the responsibility of France
